awd_titl_txt: RCN: SAVI: Adaptive Management and Use of Resilient Infrastructures in Smart Cities: Support for Global Collaborative Research on Real-Time Analytics of Heterogeneous Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Cities provide ready and efficient access to facilities and amenities through shared civil infrastructures such as transportation and healthcare. Making such critical infrastructures resilient to sudden changes, e.g., caused by large-scale disasters, requires careful management of limited and varying resources. The rapidly growing big data from both physical sensors and social media in real-time suggest an unprecedented opportunity for information technology to enable increasing efficiency and effectiveness of adaptive resource management techniques in response to sharp changes in supply and/or demand on critical infrastructures. Within the general areas of resilient infrastructures and big data, this project will focus on the integration of heterogeneous Big Data and real-time analytics that will improve the adaptive management of resources when critical infrastructures are under stress. The integration of heterogeneous data sources is essential because many kinds of physical sensors and social media provide useful information on various critical infrastructures, particularly when they are under stress. 

This Research Coordination Network (RCN) will promote meetings and activities that stimulate and enable new research on integration of heterogeneous physical sensor data and social media for real-time big data analytics in support of resilient critical infrastructures such as transportation and healthcare in smart cities.  As first example, the RCN will support participation from young faculty attending the Early Career Investigators' Workshop on Cyber-Physical Systems in Smart Cities (ECI-CPS) at CPSweek (April of each year) and young faculty attending the Workshop on Big Data Analytics for Cyber-physical Systems (BDACPS). As a second example, the RCN will support contributions to a Special Track on Big Data Analytics for Resilient Infrastructures at the IEEE Big Data Congress. As a third example, the RCN will support participation in International meetings organized by other countries, e.g., Japan's Big Data program by Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST). The project will also maintain a repository of research resources. Concretely, the RCN will actively collect and make readily available public data sets (e.g., physical and social sensor data) and software tools (e.g., to support real-time big data analytics). The technologies and tools that arise from RCN-enabled research will be applied to socially and economically impactful areas such as reducing congestion and personalized healthcare in smart cities.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 pandemic has changed fundamentally our view of how organizations and societies are structured and how they function in the “new normal”. Adaptability and resilience have become the new focus of attention and priorities, in addition to steady-state efficiency, since the steady state has become quite unstable. More generally, our social and economic environments have been changing and varying rapidly as the pandemic developed and evolved, rendering disaster management based on past experience clearly insufficient.  Disaster management must adapt and respond to the evolving challenges of a protracted and varying pandemic.

 

The RCN/SAVI: GRAIT-DM (Global Research on Applying Information Technology for Disaster Management) project has been supporting the research on detecting and tracking of physical events from streams of data produced by a variety of social and physical sensors, with focus on disaster management. From the beginning, the project sought to encourage global collaboration, a position recently strengthened by the S20 Academies Joint Statement on Pandemic Preparedness and The Role of Science (July 2021), where they explain global cooperation and collaboration are clearly needed for managing an evolving global pandemic. The GRAIT-DM has been promoting global collaboration on responsive disaster management in two aspects: (1) outreach and community building, and (2) shared research platform with open source software tools and data sets.

 

The outreach activities of RCN are characterized by long term and organized series of multi-national collaboration activities in which researchers from Japan and US interact and work together. The first two series consist of regular interactions of researchers from US and Japan in their respective PI meetings: One being the Japanese participation in NSF CPS PI meetings (annual, ongoing), and the other being the American participation in JST (Japan Science and Technology Agency) annual Joint Big Data Symposium (up to 2020). The third series consist of the three successive (from 2017 to 2020) US-Japan Workshops on Enabling Global Collaboration on Big Data Research that enabled intensive collaborative working interactions among researchers from US and Japan. Another example of international collaboration is with Brazil: the SPSAS (Sao Paulo School of Advanced Science on Learning from Data in 2019) was organized and attended by Brazilian and US researchers, including NSF representatives. The chair of SPSAS, Prof. J. E. Ferreira of USP, founded the Center on Research and Development of Live Knowledge at USP, which continues to collaborate with the GRAIT-DM RCN.

 

Through the SAVI/RCN grants, the GRAIT-DM project provided stimulus and financial support for dissemination and publication of research results in the area of real-time integrated analytics of heterogeneous big data for adaptive management and use of resilient infrastructures in responsive disaster management. Concretely, the project provided RCN Fellowships for early-career investigators to present their papers in the special tracks of relevant conferences, including IEEE BigData Congress, the SCF BigData Congress, and IEEE International Conference on Collaborative and Internet Computing.

 

At a technical level, the importance of responsive disaster management has been emphatically magnified by the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite our wishes that every wave would be the last, new variants kept appearing, demanding adaptations from every country and region. Despite significant successes such as the unprecedented fast creation, trial, production, and delivery of effective vaccines, the new waves seem to defy every strategy, from high vaccination rates in India to zero-tolerance in China. Generally, disasters introduce serious challenges by transforming a familiar environment into hostile territory. The challenge of COVID-19 pandemic is an unprecedented combination of high infection rate of SARS-COV-2 virus, with high hospitalization and mortality rates. As new variants such as the Delta raised further the infection, hospitalization, and death rates for wider age groups, new waves have overwhelmed strategies designed for previous rates. As an example, proposed epidemiological models that made assumptions about any fixed shape or number of waves have been made obsolete by the increasing rates of new variants and new waves.

 

The LITMUS/EDNA shared platform developed by the GRAIT-DM project provides software tools, data sets, and techniques that support the EBKA (Evidence-Based Knowledge Acquisition) approach. EBKA filters the noises in social media channels, including misinformation and disinformation, by combining social media data with authoritative and corroborative sources such as CDC, WHO, and reputable newspapers to separate legitimate data items from misinformation that includes fake news. Concretely, the application of EBKA in LITMUS/EDNA yields two high-confidence complementary data sets: (1) positive information of verifiable facts, and (2) negative information of confirmed fake news from disabled accounts. The LITMUS/EDNA platform is able to support several application areas, currently focusing on responsive disaster management. The capability to detect true novelty reliably increases the potential of machine learning-based software tools to help reduce the human, social, and economic costs of the pandemic, as well as future disasters.
